text: for weeks now Basra has been
experiencing a wave of anti-government
protests a few days ago they turned
violent leaving more than 20 protestors
dead they had taken to the streets
because they were frustrated by the lack
of public services and angered by
perceived corruption among officials a
water and electricity is a legitimate
right and it's not a right we should beg
for the government makes Basra beg for
water shame on them this is the
government headquarters here in Basra
it's not the only building set on fire
and the city over the past few weeks
angry protesters have set on fire
they Iranian consulate and dozens of
other buildings owned by armed Shia
groups Sanaa Jafar was one of those
injured after being shot in front of the
provincial headquarter this is the first
time he has returned to the scene since
his injury remember the blood of those
that died we were protesting to demand
our rights we demanded the right of
legitimacy the most basic right
available in the West our demand in 2018
is for drinking water the oil fields of
Warsaw generate most of Iraq's crude oil
it should be a prosperous place but
instead thousands of residents have been
poisoned after drinking water unsuitable
for consumption despite his injury
summer continues to take part in nightly
demonstrations against the government
there are no immediate solutions to the
protesters demands for safe water elq
atrocity as well as jobs
so demonstrations in Basra will continue
for some time Feroz Kieran in BBC News
Basra
